references.W98PIE01USGP: Pierson, E.D. and W.E. Rainey. 1998. Arizona myotis, Myotis occultus. In Terrestrial Mammal Species of Special Concern in California, Bolster, B.C., ed. Available online: <http://www.dfg.ca.gov/wildlife/nongame/ssc/mammals.html> [Accessed June 26, 2012].
references.B75FIN01SWGP: Findley, J. S., A. H. Harris, D. E. Wilson, and C. Jones. 1975. Mammals of New Mexico. University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 360 pages.
references.N63HAY01USGP: Hayward, B.J. 1963. A Maternity colony of Myotis occultus. Journal of Mammalogy, 44(2):279.
references.N43STA01USGP: Stager, K.E. 1943. Remarks on Myotis occultus in California. Journal of Mammalogy, 24(2):197-199.
references.A99VAL01USGP: Valdez, E.W., J.R. Choate, M.A. Bogan, and T.L. Yates. 1999. Taxonomic status of Myotis occultus. Journal of Mammalogy, 80(2):545-552.
references.R99CHU01USGP: Chung-MacCoubrey, A. 1999. Maternity roosts of bats at the Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge: a preliminary report. USDA Forest Service Proceedings RMRS-P-7.
references.A09GEL01USGP: Geluso, K. and J.N. Mink. 2009. Use of bridges by bats (Mammalia: Chiroptera) in the Rio Grande Valley, New Mexico. The Southwestern Naturalist, 54(4):421-429.
references.B86HOF01SWGP: Hoffmeister, D.F. 1986. Mammals of Arizona. University of Arizona Press. The University of Arizona Press and the Arizona Game and Fish Department, Tucson, Arizona. 602 pages.
references.R03ARI01USGP: Arizona Game and Fish Department. 2003. Myotis occultus. Unpublished abstract compiled and edited by the Heritage Data Management System, Arizona Game and Fish Department, Phoenix, Arizona.
references.A99MOR01USGP: Morrell, T.E., M.J. Rabe, J.C. deVos, Jr., H. Green, and C.R. Miller. 1999. Bats captured in two ponderosa pine habitats in north-central Arizona. The Southwestern Naturalist, 44(4):501-506.
references.L69BAR0100LA: Barbour, R. W., and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. The University Press of Kentucky. Lexington. 286 pp.

habitat_description: Myotis occultus is typically found in ponderosa pine forests, ponderosa pine woodlands, ponderosa pine savannas, oak-pine woodlands (Hoffmeister, 1986; Morrell et al., 1999; Valdez et al., 1999), riparian forests of cottonwood and willow species (Hayward, 1963; Hoffmeister, 1986; Valdez et al., 1999), mixed conifer forests, aspen-ponderosa forests (AZ Game and Fish Department, 2003), and pinyon-juniper forests (Valdez et al., 1999). It is known to roost under bridges (Geluso and Mink, 2009) and hibernates in caves within the area of its summer range (Findley et al., 1975). In Arizona, the species has been found at elevations ranging from 46 m, along the lower Colorado River, to 2627 m in the San Francisco Mountains (AZ Game and Fish Department, 2003). The Arizona myotis requires close proximity to permanent, large water bodies (Hoffmeister, 1986; AZ Game and Fish Department, 2003).
